explanation:
List of symbols needed and why they matter for checking "controlling expressions shall not be invariant":

- struct MHD_Daemon: the function inspects daemon->options and uses daemon fields (epoll_upgrade_fd, lists) in multiple ifs; need the struct layout/semantics to know whether values tested are compile-time constants or runtime-varying.

- struct MHD_Connection: the code tests connection fields (sk_nonblck, read_buffer_offset, tid, socket_fd, pool, etc.). Knowing field types and mutability is required to decide if those controlling expressions can ever vary.

- MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE: flag used in (daemon->options & MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE) — required to determine whether that bit-test is invariant.

- MHD_USE_TLS: flag used in (daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS) — needed to judge invariance of TLS-related conditionals.

- MHD_USE_THREADS: compile-time macro gating thread-related asserts — affects presence of a controlling expression.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_: macro/function used inside the assert controlling expression; definition determines whether that expression is compile-time invariant or runtime-dependent.

- MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_: used in the same assert; its semantics determine whether the assert expression can be invariant.

- MHD_get_response_element_n_: used inside an assert controlling expression; need its prototype/behavior to know if the asserted expression is constant.

- MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_UPGRADE, MHD_HEADER_KIND: constants/macros passed to MHD_get_response_element_n_; their values affect whether the call is invariant.

- connection->sk_nonblck: the if (! connection->sk_nonblck) is a controlling expression — need the field type/initialization/when it can change to decide invariance.

- MHD_socket_pair_nblk_, MHD_socket_pair_: their presence/implementations control which branch is compiled and whether the socket-pair test is invariant (some platforms may stub them out to constants).

- MHD_socket_nonblocking_: return value is checked; need its behavior to know if the test can be invariant.

- MHD_socket_nosignal_ and MSG_NOSIGNAL: used together in conditionals; definitions affect whether the branch is effectively constant.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_SELECT_, MHD_D_DOES_SCKT_FIT_FDSET_, MHD_D_GET_FD_SETSIZE_: used in a select-related if; their expansion/semantics determine if that controlling expression is compile-time constant.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_: used to guard epoll-related code; definition decides whether the epoll if-condition is invariant.

- EPOLL_SUPPORT: compile-time macro that controls presence of epoll code — needed to know whether those conditionals remain in the translation unit.

- epoll_ctl and EPOLLIN/EPOLLOUT/EPOLLPRI/EPOLLET: epoll_ctl return value is checked (if (0 != epoll_ctl(...))) — need epoll_ctl prototype/errno semantics and event constants to reason about whether that controlling expression can be invariant.

- daemon->epoll_upgrade_fd: used in an assert and in epoll_ctl calls; value/type needed to judge invariance of epoll-related checks.

- MHD_PANIC and MHD_socket_last_strerr_: used in epoll error handling; while not a controlling expression themselves, they appear in branches taken when epoll_ctl fails — include for context of errno-based conditions.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_: used in an if to decide insertion; definition determines whether that controlling expression can be constant.

- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET and MHD_EPOLL_STATE_UNREADY: constants used to initialise urh fields; their values may matter if compared elsewhere (and for completeness of invariant analysis).

- MHD_pool_get_free, RESERVE_EBUF_SIZE, MHD_pool_allocate, MHD_pool_deallocate: used in the final TLS buffer-allocation branch; avail < RESERVE_EBUF_SIZE is a controlling expression — need these symbols to determine whether avail (pool free space) can ever be a compile-time constant or is runtime-varying.

Rationale: MISRA C forbids invariant controlling expressions (except the listed exceptions). To determine if any 'if' or loop condition in this function is invariant, the analyzer must know which symbols/macros used in those controlling expressions are compile-time constants or evaluate at runtime and whether their values can change. The symbols above cover all macros, flags, struct fields and functions that appear directly in controlling expressions (and closely related compile-time guards) in MHD_response_execute_upgrade_.
